Chapter on the Appearance of Siddhi (11-12)

At that time, the World-Honored One again observed the great assembly. In order to fulfill all wishes, he again spoke the Dharma phrases of perfect wisdom of the definitive wisdom of the immeasurable gates of the three times. Observing the great assembly is not without causes and conditions.
First, with the Buddha's mind, he observes the species, characteristics, and essence of those sentient beings, which Dharma they are able to receive, and by what kind they can be benefited.
Having observed in this way, one should know that they will attain entry into those Dharma gates.
In order to speak of this, he first observes the capacities.
The immeasurable definitive wisdom gates of the three times refer to the immeasurable unobstructed wisdom gates of the three times in a single thought.

The Buddha uses various skillful means to expound this wonderful Dharma, and all sentient beings each attain certainty according to their respective capacities. Since the gates are immeasurable, it is said to be the gate of immeasurable Dharma.

The Buddha observes the great assembly and expounds this gate of the Dharma realm of universal access, wishing to enable each to attain certainty according to their original affinities. Therefore, it is called the gate of certain knowledge.

As for the Dharma phrases, it means first touching on the phenomena, and from the phenomena one is able to give rise to the principle. Therefore, it is called a phrase, which is the basis for verses. Using names and phrases, it explains the Dharma of the world's phrases and verses.

As for being complete, entering this Dharma gate is able to give rise to the Dharma gate and give rise to the Dharma realm of the self-realized secret Dharma of the formless TathÄgata. It is about to use such Dharma to fulfill all sentient beings, not allowing them to pass in vain.
This phrase is precisely a verse. It has yet to be collated with the phrase. Later, it will be made into a verse according to the meaning.

Space is without defilements and without self-nature, able to bestow various skillful wisdoms means that the mind of omniscience is equal to space, without defilements, immeasurable, unobstructed, and without discrimination. This is the Dharma of the great emptiness and direct realization of the Buddhas.
Without self-nature means that this empty and undefiled pure Dharma realm also has no self-nature and cannot be grasped.
Because this great emptiness is also without self-nature, it is able to give rise to omniscience, which is a different name for skillful wisdom.

If it were not skillful wisdom, how could it accord with the various mental activities of all sentient beings, manifest the body that they wish to see, speak the Dharma that they should hear, and accord with their capacity for understanding, all without falsehood, and enter the Dharma realm of equality? This is the ultimate skillfulness within skillfulness.

Because equality and emptiness also have no self-nature, and the arising and ceasing of characteristics also have no nature, therefore, one is able to freely generate skillful wisdom in accord with the wishes of all sentient beings.
It is beyond conceptual thought and measurement.

Because the intrinsic nature is always empty, dependent arising is profound and difficult to see means that this emptiness that cannot be attained is precisely the body of the eternally abiding Dharma Buddha.

Because it is free from the eight inverted characteristics such as emptiness and non-emptiness, it is the profound dependent arising, the unconditioned and unfabricated that is able to universally respond to sentient beings without moving from the Dharma realm, with the related responses like the moon appearing in clear water.

Such dependent arising is inconceivable. The intrinsic nature of emptiness always exists, it is not that it did not exist before and now exists, or that it existed and then becomes nonexistent again, therefore it is called the intrinsic nature of emptiness is like this.

Always advancing in the superior practice, granting the unsurpassed fruit as one wishes means that one always cultivates such Dharma practices, and even the great emptiness cannot be attained, because it has no intrinsic nature.

Just like the great emptiness, it can give rise to myriad practices. This practice of the profound and equal Dharma realm, if the practitioner can always practice like this, then one can fulfill the wishes of sentient beings as they think of them, and even grant them the unsurpassed great vow.
Just as all palaces in the realms of existence are based on space, moving without attachment, this is fearing that people will not believe and understand, so it further uses an analogy to illustrate.
Just as all worlds in the cosmos are based on space and can abide, yet this great emptiness has no further basis, and does not think:
All worlds are born from me and abide based on me.
This world also does not repay the kindness of space, but seeks to repay it, not thinking:
By the power of this space, it allows me to attain such peace and security.
Why is this?
Because space is not seen to have the activity of creation, therefore it does not repay kindness.

Therefore, the next assembly says, This pure Dharma is also like this, born of the purity of the three existences without remainder. The combined statement is that the practices explained above are also the same as space, removing the obstacles of the three existences without remainder, and able to give rise to the pure Dharma, which is the birth of the Dharma-nature pure wondrous body that is praised.
Next, it says, Because of cultivating this in the past, the majestic birth attained the practices of all TathÄgatas. It further cites the past as evidence.
Majestic birth refers to being born first, and being born first means being the first to awaken to this Dharma.
If one awakens to this Dharma, then it is the inexhaustible adornment, the inexhaustible adornment of the wondrous treasury of samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, spiritual powers, and wondrous adornments.
That is to say, a past bodhisattva named ViÅ›iá¹£á¹­a-ÄyatanavyÅ«ha, who is a Buddha's disciple.
He is a practitioner of the past, like the saying born first.
The Sanskrit word vibhu means soon fulfilling all wealth, referring to the wealth of the Dharma, which is used to adorn one's body.
This enlightened one has already attained such a Dharma, and all Buddhas have also attained this Dharma.
Next, it says There is no other phrase that can be obtained, to illuminate the world like the World-Honored One, which means:
If one leaves this and seeks elsewhere in other phrases, there is no way to accomplish such an inconceivable Dharma realm.
Even if one seeks in the middle, there is no principle to be found.
It is like seeking oil in water, which is impossible.
If one can attain this self-realization that is not dependent on others, one will be able to illuminate the world, like the sun shining.
It is also like when a Buddha appears in the world, universally acting as a great light for the ignorant world.

Expounding the extremely pure practice method, profound, vast, inexhaustible, and free from discrimination means that the Buddha expounds this extremely pure, non-discriminating, free from discrimination, profound, self-realized Dharma. This Dharma is profound and vast, inconceivable, indestructible, and inexhaustible.
This is the meaning of praising the Dharma's virtues.
At that time, the World-Honored Vairocana, having spoken this verse, observed VajrapÄá¹‡i and the entire great assembly, and said to VajrapÄá¹‡i:
Good sons!
Each should manifest the spiritual powers of the Dharma realm. Spiritual powers are also the spiritual transformations of movement and use.
This spiritual transformation has the meaning of vastness, from one to many.
The words that flow out of siddhi.

If sentient beings see such a Dharma, they will give rise to joy and delight, and attain the bliss of abiding - the Buddha observes that the great assembly is not without causes and conditions, and wishes to have them each speak, flowing out from the inconceivable Dharma realm, the power of sovereign spiritual penetrations, the words of siddhi.
This flowing out is called a gate, which is a Sanskrit word with many meanings, but here it means to flow out.
It means that from the Buddha's mind of the Dharma realm of self-realization, countless skillful wisdom gates flow out.

This is just like each bodhisattva and vajra being the virtue of the TathÄgata's inner realization, and from this, Dharma gates manifest. There are those who transmit the Dharma and gather sentient beings through the gates, leading a certain type to enter through this gate and reach the ground of omniscience.

The Buddha's intention is to have them each explain the gateway to entering the true nature. If there are sentient beings with the potential for that, they will give rise to joy and activate wholesome roots, and will then accomplish the supreme practice from this gateway, abiding in the TathÄgata's practice of peace and joy.
At that time, the VajrapÄá¹‡is bowed to the World-Honored Vairocana, saying, Thus, Dharma Lord!
In accordance with the instructions means to follow the Buddha's command without daring to disobey.
However, since the TathÄgata is the Dharma Lord, if they each explain differently in the presence of the Dharma Lord, it is not appropriate.
This is requesting the Buddha to explain himself, so that everyone can hear it.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
Explaining in this way in the presence of the World-Honored One according to one's own understanding is not appropriate.
This is a reversal of the text.
At that time, the VajrapÄá¹‡is again requested the Buddha, saying:
We only pray that the World-Honored One, out of compassion for us, will manifest the words that flow out of the siddhis.
Why is it so?
It is not appropriate to proclaim what one has realized in the presence of the Venerable Blessed One - what is the meaning of this?
The TathÄgata is the supreme and unsurpassed Dharma King, because he has directly realized, thoroughly understood, and clearly seen without remainder in this Dharma.
We have each attained realization according to our own mental capacity through the Buddha's compassionate power.
If we were to proclaim it ourselves in the presence of the great Dharma Lord, it would not be appropriate.
This is the meaning of being ashamed, humble, and retiring.
Having expressed this meaning, we wish for the Buddha to explain it himself.
Why is this?
It is because the sentient beings of the future will encounter this Dharma and attain great benefits, and will open the Buddha's insight and quickly accomplish the TathÄgata's blissful practice.
Having said this, the TathÄgata said to VajrapÄá¹‡i and the others:
Excellent, excellent, good men!
In this Dharma Vinaya taught by the TathÄgata, all are praised, namely those who are ashamed.

If there are good sons and good women who see such a Dharma, they will quickly give rise to two things, namely, not doing what should not be done, and being praised by the multitude. The Buddha praises the meaning of this statement:
Although these good people have attained good understanding in the Dharma gates they have entered, they dare not speak out of respect and shame for the TathÄgata.
One should know that this is precisely the characteristic of good people, thus it is said excellent, excellent.
Next, he leads them by means of their practice, thus it is said in the Dharma and Vinaya taught by the TathÄgata, only one Dharma is always praised, namely shame.
The Sanskrit sound in the West is different from the names for shame and conscience.
They explain to each other, What is shame and conscience?
It is said to be having shame.
If a person has a mind of shame, then they have shame and conscience.
The TathÄgata always praises this one Dharma.
If a person can have a sense of shame, they will accomplish the practice of secrecy, and it should be known that this is the place where the traces are revealed.
Because of having a sense of shame, one can possess two dharmas:
First, all activities that should not be done are not done.
Why should they not be done?
It is like worldly people, each observing the things that should not be done within their own nature, and then not daring to do them. The world calls them people with a sense of shame.
Now this good man is also like this. Within the nature of the TathÄgata, he observes for himself and knows that all evil deeds in this Dharma should not be done.
This is the first.
Because of not doing evil, he is praised by the TathÄgata.

Not only is he praised by the TathÄgata, he is also constantly praised and proclaimed by the multitudes of devas, humans, asuras, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and ordinary and holy beings in the ten directions. This is the karmic result of not doing many evil deeds.
Moreover, being praised by the assembly is the meaning of all wholesome dharmas that accompany it.
Because it is endowed with all wholesomeness, it is praised by the great assembly.
There are two more things, namely, causing the unattained to be attained means causing the unattained to be attained, reaching the wonderful treasure island of omniscience.

Because of having shame, one is able to practice the two dharmas. Because of attaining the former two, one is able to reach the place to be reached, because what was not realized in the past is now realized, and what was not heard in the past is now heard.
This is the first.
Second, because of reaching what has not been reached, one is born in the lineage of the TathÄgatas.
Together with all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas in one place, always inseparable from the subtle and supreme progress.
This is the second.
There are two more things, namely, abiding in morality means the meaning of morality is to remove heat and attain coolness.
If one is hot, one thinks of a cool pond or a cool room. If one enters well, one immediately leaves behind the afflictions of heat.
It is also like a person with a fever who gets rid of the heat and poison, and then the body and mind are cool and one attains good comfort. The meaning is the same as the meaning of coolness.
Bodhisattvas, due to the accomplishment of the nature precepts, do not rely on the precepts of prohibition but naturally have them.
It is like the great ocean, whose nature is such that it does not harbor corpses, and it is not that some person or thing makes it so.
It is not the same as the precepts of the Å›rÄvakas.
The second Dharma is that due to possessing the precepts, one always gets to be born among humans and gods.

This refers to those who have not yet attained the stage of the Dharma body. In every life, one always remains among humans and gods, gets to leave behind hindrances, see the Buddha, and hear the Dharma. This is the great benefit.ğŸ”½Excellent! Listen attentively!
Contemplate it well!

I shall proclaim the true words of accomplishment, the corresponding phrases that flow out - in this good there are two meanings of gentleman, referring to the Buddha praising their virtuous qualities, and perhaps informing them to listen well.
Flow out is like the Buddha emitting light, first having a place of origin, referring to the places such as the face, the mark of a tuft of white hair between the eyebrows, the crown protrusion, etc.
After performing the Buddha's work and completing it, it returns and enters again.
This flowing out of true words is also like this, one should know it flows out from within the true words.
It refers to the flowing out of the fruits of accomplishment.

This true word originally comes from the virtues of the Tathagata's own realization, appearing in the Buddha's mind ground, creating immeasurable Dharma gates and performing the great work of the Buddha.
After performing the Buddha's work, it causes the sentient beings to be saved to enter the Buddha's Dharma realm through this gate, and therefore it is called flowing out.

Therefore, the next line says The corresponding phrases that flow out from this, for the bodhisattvas who cultivate enlightenment through the mantra gate, they will quickly attain the fruit of mantra siddhi in this. The fruit here refers to the attainment of the inconceivable fruit of omniscience.
The first line after that says If the practitioner sees the maá¹‡á¸ala and is approved and accomplished with true words, from here onwards it further clarifies the method of subsequent offerings.
First, one obtains the vision of the maá¹‡á¸ala, and it is not just a matter of obtaining the vision, one must be added by the teacher and introduced, as explained before.
It is not just a matter of obtaining entry, but subsequent practice.
Because of practicing according to the Dharma, one obtains the approval and transmission of the Dharma from the ÄcÄrya.
Because of obtaining the approval and consecration, the next line says the accomplishment of mantras.

Next, in the Chapter on Recitation in the World, first contemplate in the center of the circle, there is the mantra syllable wheel surrounding, reciting from head to tail. At the time, from the first syllable, enter the mouth and flow into the body, just like inhaling and pervading the body.
This is the empowerment of the Tathagata's own spiritual power.
Reciting like this, one can remove all the karmic defilements of sentient beings.
After pervading the body like this, return from the mouth and enter under the feet of the honored one, pervading to the original place.
In this way, when each syllable flows in, the next syllable immediately continues without interruption, connecting in sequence.

If a beginner is afraid of the mind being scattered and cannot accomplish it like this, they should only contemplate the seed syllable, doing it as before, until the mind is familiar and gradually add the syllables.
Move this section into the previous chapter, as explained before, seeing the maá¹‡á¸ala and also attaining entry, performing all Dharma activities up to the abhiá¹£eka.

Having received the Dharma, one practices in accordance with the Dharma, well understands the sequential methods and uses within the mantras, is clear and unobstructed, and is able to transmit the Dharma and obtain the teacher's approval.
The sutra refers to the Venerable One, who is the teacher.
Moreover, able to give rise to the bodhi mind means seeking the self-mastery of the Tathagata and universally benefiting all sentient beings, and thus practicing this conduct, not for other matters.
Deeply believing in compassion without stinginess means having a decisive and correct faith in the inconceivable Dharma of the profound and vast, without any doubts.
Moreover, having no stinginess in mind regarding wealth and Dharma, with a mind of great compassion and pity for all, always engaging in benefiting others, not seeking one's own benefit.
Abiding in self-discipline means disciplining one's own six sense faculties, which is the precept of inherent morality.
One who can skillfully distinguish the dharmas that arise from conditions is like a bright mirror, clearly reflecting various colors in front of it.

Such dharmas are not originally existent in the mirror, nor do they come from outside, and one should know that the two dharmas combined also cannot produce them. Yet they are clearly manifest, ungraspable, unobtainable, and also neither existent nor nonexistent. They are only visible due to the combination of various conditions.
One should know that all dharmas are also like this, up to the ten analogies, which one is able to penetrate.
Having contemplated in this way, one should also contemplate the fruits of mantra siddhi in the same way.
These siddhi characteristics arise from the combination of the reciter and the mantra of the deity, and there are then all kinds of inconceivable things.
The reflections in the mirror of the dharma realm cannot be grasped, yet various accomplishments are possible.
Upholding the precepts refers to the precepts that are the equipment for maintaining the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and within them, all the rules are well upheld.
For this reason, one does not violate the samaya precepts and attains the accomplishment of siddhi.
Abiding well in the many practices refers to the signs of accomplishment of the superior, middling, and inferior methods in the gateway of mantras.
Being well-versed in each and every practice to be learned is precisely abiding well within the superior, middling, and inferior methods.
Endowed with skillful means refers to thoroughly understanding the TathÄgata's skillful means.

When practicing the mantra path, one may violate the precepts of the renunciant and the two vehicles, but one should not give rise to such confusion and think, Because of this matter, I have violated this precept.
One should know that abandoning evil destinies is a matter of the mind, and harboring evil thoughts interferes with proper practice.
Why is this?
The TathÄgata's skillful means are solely for such great matters.
If it causes one to abandon the skillful means and pure precepts of the vehicles, and obstructs the practice of the perfect mantra, there is no such principle.
Therefore, when practitioners have transgressions, they should think like this:
I now aspire to seek the unsurpassed great vehicle, in order to universally benefit all sentient beings.
Since I cannot accomplish both tasks, I have transgressed in this matter.
If I attain accomplishment of the fruit, I will then repent.
Because this wholesome mind is not a cause for breaking precepts, it is not called breaking precepts.
Courageous has the same meaning as explained in the section on the master and disciple.

Knowing the proper time and improper time means that in the mantra approach, each and every method should not be done out of order, with what should come first placed last and what should come last placed first. What should be done first should be done first, and what should be done later should be done likewise, which is called the proper time.
Even eating, drinking, sleeping, and various other activities each have their proper and improper times.
If a mantra practitioner sleeps during the day or does not sleep all night, such activities are also not samaya, not the proper time.
Delighting in giving means that the bodhisattva of mantra practice always uses the giving of wealth and Dharma to attract sentient beings and cause them to enter the Buddha's path.
If one is unable to do this according to one's ability, then one violates the vidyÄdhara precepts.

The mind is without fear means that if one is in a crowd, there may be sentient beings with different understandings and views, who may ask questions to resolve doubts or test the depth, then at that time one should abide in the Dharma, with a fearless mind and an unattached mind, and explain according to the questions, causing them to enter the correct view, and one's mind should not be timid.
Diligent in cultivating the mantra practice method means that in the practice approach, one should never interrupt or stagnate.

If one were to abandon it midway, it would not be a sign of diligence. One who should attain will not attain, and one who has attained will regress and lose it, which would be an obstacle on the path.

Therefore, the practitioner single-mindedly diligently practices as if putting out a fire on their head. Because of diligence and non-negligence, one can attain the Buddha's insight in this very life, let alone the various other auxiliary practices.
If not, one violates the samaya precepts.
Penetrating the true meaning of mantras means knowing the profound intentions in the superior, middling, and inferior accomplishments.

In each syllable, the male and female sounds, etc., from the entrance gate up to the attainment of Buddhahood, one should skillfully distinguish the characteristics of the unobstructed and obstructed within them.
Why is this so?

These mantras are precisely the virtues realized by the Tathagata himself. Adorned with this Dharma body, he causes all sentient beings to each see the true aspect according to their karmic affinities.
If one enters a single syllable, it is endowed with immeasurable merits of the gateway, without duality or distinction.
Always delighting in sitting in meditation and delighting in accomplishing attainments means, within the gateway of mantras, the mind abides in a single object without distraction.
Like contemplating a syllable, contemplating a sound, or the seed of the deity, the mind does not externally depend on a single thing, and one is then able to attain great accomplishment.
If the mind is in distraction, even if one spends countless eons seeking accomplishment, it will still be unobtainable, let alone attaining the benefits of the Dharma in a single lifetime.
Next, the characteristics of mantra accomplishment are explained.
Some may have doubts and say:
In the unconditioned Dharma of the true characteristics of all dharmas, how can there be such various phenomena?
Now, in order to awaken them, it is answered:
This matter truly exists, one should not give rise to doubt.
For now, take worldly matters as an analogy.
Moreover, Lord of Mysteries!

It is like in the desire realm there is the light of self-mastery, joy, and satisfaction, up to all the desire realm gods. As explained in the Mahayana, there are thirty-six realms in the desire realm, namely the cold and hot hells each have eight, totaling sixteen. There are also the four great continents, and each of these four continents has two sub-continents, totaling twelve sub-continents. Together with the previous twenty-eight, plus the six heavens and the animals and ghosts, there are thirty-six. Because of the power of this light of self-mastery, joy, and satisfaction, various kinds of colorful sensual pleasures are manifested, and in one moment they can fill these thirty-six realms.

It also says intoxicated by this, producing various wonderful things, up to also enjoying them oneself. What is meant is that for all the gods and goddesses, the inner and outer realms of sentient beings and insentient beings are manifested.
Like manifesting the flavors of food, music, and so forth, each can be manifested and enjoyed in the present.
If one sees the female form and other bodies, one can also enjoy the five desires, each according to their desires.
It is because they encounter extremely wonderful five desire objects that their minds all become confused and intoxicated.
How much more so for the true words of the TathÄgata, which are able to universally manifest the form bodies and perform Buddha's work?
Moreover, good sons!

It is like how MaheÅ›vara has a mantra called the Mantra of the Birth of the Supreme Mind. By the power of this mantra, he is able to create great transformations in an instant, manifesting in every single sentient being in this trichiliocosm, manifesting the matters of love and benefit, and according to their enjoyment, all of it is real and not false.
Moreover, he transforms the bodies of the Pure Abodes and the subtle matters of enjoyment, as explained in the sÅ«tras. How much more so for the power of the TathÄgata's mantra?
Setting this aside for now, like how a worldly magician is still able to use their mantra to manifest various gardens, fruits, vehicles, people, animals, and so forth.

It is also like the asuras who have their own mantras, which can transform their bodies to be the same as Åšakra, and sit in the SudharmÄ Hall of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, causing all the gods to give rise to doubts and strangeness.
It is also like the people of the world who have mantras that can subdue all poisons and the various afflictions of cold and heat.
There is also the god Ká¹›ttikÄ who has his own mantra, which can cause great epidemics for all people.
There are even people in the world who, by means of mantras, can transform fire into cold and transform ice into heat.
How much more so for the mantras empowered by the TathÄgata's own sovereign spiritual powers, which do not universally pervade the Dharma realm and greatly perform Buddha-works?
Therefore, one should give rise to faith and believe that this majestic power and function is true and not false.
The reciter, before attaining siddhi, will have doubts about whether this matter is certain or not.
Such an inconceivable fruition, if one were to discriminate it with the mind, one would never attain the principle.
In order to eliminate this doubt, the previous analogy is given.

However, the power of this mantra does not come from the mantra, is not in the reciter, and also does not enter the body and speech of the empowered one. When seeking its nature and characteristics, it cannot be found, yet it can accomplish all things as appropriate. This is the profound dependent origination, the nature of phenomena arising from various conditions, like the water moon and mirror image, the inconceivable dependent origination.
Good sons!
Due to the power of mantra empowerment, it arises as it is, without transgression.
Because the samÄdhi does not transgress, it refers to the original accomplishment of mantra siddhi.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata directly realizes such inconceivable dharmas, namely, the essence of the letter A, which from the very beginning is endowed with immeasurable sovereign power and inconceivable power.
The essence of this siddhi is eternally abiding and unchanging, but because practitioners themselves do not understand and realize it, they do not attain such fruits.
Now, by practicing this, one purifies one's bodily, verbal, and mental actions. If one can accord with the Dharma, one will accomplish it oneself.
All dharmas are like this, and will never be in vain.
This inconceivable fruit will naturally arise when the various conditions come together, just like the tides of the great ocean never miss their appointed time.

Moreover, this mantra itself has no beginning and no end. If it had a beginning and an end, then it would be exhausted, and would be a dharma of impermanence and decay. How can it be called the sovereign power of the TathÄgata himself?

Because the essence of this Dharma transcends the three times while always being in the three times, therefore the Buddha's work done in the three periods of time is naturally always unceasing, never missing the appointed time.
It is like the water of the great ocean, which when the bright moon is full, naturally surges without missing its appointed time.

The principle of the profound and inconceivable dependent origination means that if the fundamental mantra is not accomplished beforehand, then it will not be able to respond to the stimulus and not lose the time limit.
Even if the mantra has this power, if the practitioner's practice is not yet in accord, then it will also not be able to cause the empowerment to manifest.
However, the conditions come together and are accomplished by themselves, so one should know that it does not come from there, does not go from here, and is also not in both places.

Without nature, it is able to come together through conditions and accomplish the fruit of siddhi, and it is also not naturally existent. One should know that this is the profound inconceivable fruit of the dharma realm.
Arising from conditions, it is always without nature, and is inconceivable.
If the practitioner practices without interruption, then it will certainly be the ultimate fruit in accord with the ultimate principle.
Such an ultimate principle cannot be known through conceptual thought and discrimination.
This is encouraging belief by bringing up the previous analogy.
Therefore, good sons!

Following and penetrating the inconceivable Dharma-nature, always uninterrupted, the path of mantras means that this inconceivable fruit of mantra, since it is not known by discrimination, and also not attained by the practice of small antidotes with a limited scope of power, therefore only those with firm faith and power can enter it.

Therefore, first a metaphor is given, and then the ultimate principle is clarified, encouraging one to rely on this gate, contemplate the ultimate principle of inconceivable dependent origination, always seek to penetrate such inconceivable Dharma-nature, and cultivate the practice of mantra in accordance with this principle without interruption, naturally attaining Buddhahood.
This path of mantra is precisely the place where the inconceivable Dharma arises.
Because of the inconceivable cause, one attains the inconceivable fruit.

At that time, the World-Honored One again relied on the power of unobstructed access to the three times and the inconceivable power of the TathÄgata's empowerment. The power of the samÄdhi of the pure treasury of adornments means relying on the power of unobstructed access to the three times and the inconceivable power of the Buddha. There are two kinds of reliance here.

This samÄdhi is the place of reliance for the inconceivable power of unobstructed access to the three times and empowerment. Relying on this dharma essence, one can accomplish the inconceivable activities of the TathÄgata, namely, universally pervading the three times in the ten directions, universally benefiting all sentient beings, and causing them to ultimately abide in the single initial ground of omniscience.
This inconceivable reliance of the TathÄgata on the dharma realized by oneself, adorned and purified by immeasurable samÄdhis, wisdoms, and powers, is precisely the essence of the mantra.
This is the treasury of the TathÄgata's myriad virtues, adorned without end, without deficiency, and perfectly accomplished, the characteristic of completeness.

At that time, the World-Honored One emerged from the samÄdhi of the inexhaustible realm and the inexhaustible expression of speech, relying on the power of the Dharma realm, the unequaled power, and the faith and understanding of perfect enlightenment, and with a single sound, emitted it in four directions.
It means that from the letter A, three letters emerge to form four letters. These four combine into one and are spread throughout all places.

When the practitioner first cultivates the supramundane contemplation method, they first contemplate the deity. Relying on the painted image, they contemplate well. If one obtains such events, their mind will double in faith and joy. Due to this faith, their mind becomes pure. Gradually, they will not grasp at equality, the mind being non-dual. This non-duality is also removed, without the view of middle and extremes.
Removing all mental conditions, the myriad dharmas are equal. At that time, it is called the sign of equipoise.

Although the various characteristics have not yet been accomplished when they appear, they can gradually be accomplished by this, so it is said that they are for the stage that is not yet equipoise. [My] private opinion is that it is like the world's stage that has not yet reached concentration.
Taking one of those minds, placing the mind in the mind, realizing the extremely pure phrase, stainless, peaceful, and unmoving, not discriminating like a mirror, manifesting in a very subtle way.

For those who delight in cause and effect, the secret Dharma is not something that foolish people can know, the mantras and the characteristics of all mantras. If a person has this thought in this mantra practice:
